subject: Re: Conditional tearDown()
msgSnippet: No, you have a good point. The problem is that my test writes to the database, then I call the method that I m unit testing which performs several database
messageBody:
No, you have a good point.

The problem is that my test writes to the database, then I call the
method that I'm unit testing which performs several database functions
within a transaction, then I read from the database again to test the
values. The test could fail at any one of these three points.

Your suggestion of cleaning up code though made me look at the
transactional method I was testing though...it turns out I was missing
a rollback() call, so thanks! But that still doesn't solve the
problem I have with three points of failure within my test. If you
have any ideas as to how to get around this, I'm all ears.

-Brian

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Jason Rogers" <jacaetevha@f...> wrote:
> Could you not use the opportunity to clean up your code such that
you
> don't need to visually inspect the DB? I realize that there may be
> times when you absolutely need the visual inspection (though I can't
> think of one off the bat), nevertheless, this seems like a subtle
form
> of test dependencies or spaghetti code, or some other code-smell.
Sorry
> if that sounds harsh -- I am certainly not trying to be judgemental,
> just reflective.
>
> =jason
